ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.
M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Parent: For my child, taking medication for ADHD is (harmful to beneficial) / Child: Taking medication for ADHD is (harmful to beneficial)
Parent: For my child, taking medication for ADHD is (pleasant to unpleasant) / Child: Taking medication for ADHD is (pleasant to unpleasant)
Parent: For my child, taking medication for ADHD is (worthless to useful) / Child: Taking medication for ADHD is (worthless to useful)
Parent: Parent(s) want the subject to take medicine for ADHD regularly / Child: My parent(s) want me to take medicine for ADHD regularly
Parent: Most people who are important to me want my child to take medicine for ADHD regularly / Child: Other people who are important to me want me to take medicine for ADHD regularly

Parent: ADHD is caused by differences in how messages are sent and received in parts of my child's brain that control attention. / Child: ADHD is caused by differences in how messages are sent and received in parts of my brain that control attention.

Parent: ADHD medicine works by helping my child's brain send and receive messages in the parts that control attention. / Child: ADHD medicine works by helping my brain send and receive messages in the parts that control attention.
Parent: I often argue with my child about taking ADHD medicine / Child: I often argue with my parents about taking ADHD medicine
Parent: I am confident that my child could take medicine for ADHD daily if he/she wanted to / Child: I am confident that I could take medicine for ADHD daily if I wanted to
Parent: For my child, taking medicine daily is (easy to difficult) / Child: For me to take medicine daily is (easy to difficult)
Parent: When my child takes their ADHD medication they feel (Unfocused to Focused) / Child: When I take my ADHD medication I feel (Unfocused to Focused)
Parent: When my child takes their ADHD medication they feel (Not like myself to Like myself) / Child: When I take my ADHD medication I feel (Not like myself to Like myself)
Parent: When my child takes their ADHD medication they feel (Antisocial to Social) / Child: When I take my ADHD medication I feel (Antisocial to Social)
